content.raw: Sorry, I'm late to this discussion. A tree has a lot of computational advantages and is preferred by people doing control. Maybe @hsu can chime in?
content.html: Sorry, I'm late to this discussion. A tree has a lot of computational advantages and is preferred by people doing control. Maybe @hsu can chime in?

update.description:
Classes to manage transformation in a tree structure where each frame element has a parent, a pose and unique children. Features:

* Change the local pose of frame elements
* Get a transformation between 2 frames
update.title: Frame_graph

content.raw: Yeah, let's decline this for now and work on the alternative implementation together.
content.html: Yeah, let's decline this for now and work on the alternative implementation together.

content.raw:
Yeah, Dijkstra could be slow, but the size of the graphs we're using is small, and as Ian mentioned we can derive a specific tree structure for any application that only needs a tree. We can also run dijkstra once on start, or when a node is added, and maintain the shortest path information. I think there are also faster algorithms than Dijkstra.

Graphs are needed by Gazebo, so I don't see an alternative right now.
content.html:
Yeah, Dijkstra could be slow, but the size of the graphs we're using is small, and as Ian mentioned we can derive a specific tree structure for any application that only needs a tree. We can also run dijkstra once on start, or when a node is added, and maintain the shortest path information. I think there are also faster algorithms than Dijkstra.

Graphs are needed by Gazebo, so I don't see an alternative right now.

content.raw: It doesn't look like there is a need for a tree implementation in ign-math, so we should not keep extra code around just for the pleasure of maintaining it. Should I decline this pull request and create a new one when Nate's implementation is ready?
content.html: It doesn't look like there is a need for a tree implementation in ign-math, so we should not keep extra code around just for the pleasure of maintaining it. Should I decline this pull request and create a new one when Nate's implementation is ready?

content.raw: Nate's implementation is more generic and fits the concept of a graph better while the current implementation is essentially a tree. Later on I wonder if it make sense to make Hugo's implementation derive from Nate's and override the `FrameGraph::Path` function to perform faster tree traversal. The current implementation also has useful functionalities for understanding path strings but various parts will require refactoring to make things work together.
content.html: Nate's implementation is more generic and fits the concept of a graph better while the current implementation is essentially a tree. Later on I wonder if it make sense to make Hugo's implementation derive from Nate's and override the FrameGraph::Path function to perform faster tree traversal. The current implementation also has useful functionalities for understanding path strings but various parts will require refactoring to make things work together.

content.raw: The graph is more general than the tree, I agree. I was just thinking Djikistra could be slow.
content.html: The graph is more general than the tree, I agree. I was just thinking Djikistra could be slow.

content.raw: A scene graph should be compatible with `FrameGraph`. I think every tree can be represented by `FrameGraph`, right?
content.html: A scene graph should be compatible with FrameGraph. I think every tree can be represented by FrameGraph, right?

content.raw: A scene graph maybe?
content.html: A scene graph maybe?

content.raw: Since a graph is more general than a tree (a tree is a graph without cycles), I'm not sure we need to separately support trees. Is there a use case or need for a `FrameTree` in addition to a `FrameGraph`?
content.html: Since a graph is more general than a tree (a tree is a graph without cycles), I'm not sure we need to separately support trees. Is there a use case or need for a FrameTree in addition to a FrameGraph?

content.raw: Would it make sense to have both a FrameTree and a FrameGraph?
content.html: Would it make sense to have both a FrameTree and a FrameGraph?

I had some trouble creating cycles using the current setup. I played around with the code a bit, and came up with a FrameGraph that stores a list of frames and a list of edges between frames. This approach allows cycles. The code is in the frames branch. It's a bit rough right now and a departure from what was done here. Take a look and let me know what you think about this direction.

Some cool things about the frames branch:

  • Dijktra's algorithm is implemented in the FrameGraph::Path function.
  • It's possible to initialize a FrameGraph using C++11 list initializers:
FrameGraph graph(
// The list of frames
{
  {"a", Pose3d::Zero},
  {"b", Pose3d::Zero},
  {"c", Pose3d::Zero}
},
// The edges
{
  {"a", "b"},
  {"a", "c"},
  {"c", "b"}
});
  • It should be easy to add iterators for depth-first and bread-first searches.
  • A root node is not required.

content.raw: I just added support for this.
content.html: I just added support for this.

content.raw:
This is because I was not sure deep copy of frame graphs should be in this PR, and I didn't want anyone to assume they were implemented (and find that multiple frameGraph instances share the same dataPtr).
I am happy to add a proper implementation if you see a case for it.
content.html: This is because I was not sure deep copy of frame graphs should be in this PR, and I didn't want anyone to assume they were implemented (and find that multiple frameGraph instances share the same dataPtr). I am happy to add a proper implementation if you see a case for it.

content.raw:
RelativePose constructor is from src to dst:

`RelativePose::RelativePose(const FrameWeakPtr &_srcFrame, const FrameWeakPtr &_dstFrame)`
content.html:
RelativePose constructor is from src to dst:

RelativePose::RelativePose(const FrameWeakPtr &_srcFrame, const FrameWeakPtr &_dstFrame)

content.raw:
looking at FrameGraph API:

`FrameGraph::Pose(const std::string &_dst, const std::string &_src) const`

`FrameGraph::CreateRelativePose(const std::string &_srcPath, const std::string &_dstPath) const;`

One goes from `dst` to `src` while the other is `srcPath` to `dstPath`. Should the source and destination order be consistent?
content.html:
looking at FrameGraph API:

FrameGraph::Pose(const std::string &_dst, const std::string &_src) const

FrameGraph::CreateRelativePose(const std::string &_srcPath, const std::string &_dstPath) const;

One goes from dst to src while the other is srcPath to dstPath. Should the source and destination order be consistent?

content.raw:
I can see the benefits of this aliasing mechanism, especially in the case where a large number of lookup are performed.
The code in this PR assumes infrequent lookups (to create RelativePose objects), and transformation calculations without any lookup (using the RelativePose and the precomputed vector of frames to traverse). This model, along with the tree structure, seemed well suited for the SDF and Gazebo upgrade.

Having said that, what Tully describes can also be used here too. Is there a particular use case that should be considered?
content.html:
I can see the benefits of this aliasing mechanism, especially in the case where a large number of lookup are performed. The code in this PR assumes infrequent lookups (to create RelativePose objects), and transformation calculations without any lookup (using the RelativePose and the precomputed vector of frames to traverse). This model, along with the tree structure, seemed well suited for the SDF and Gazebo upgrade.

Having said that, what Tully describes can also be used here too. Is there a particular use case that should be considered?
